name: sulfate pulp production, from softwood, bleached | sulfate pulp, bleached | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19070/documentation

This dataset has been extrapolated from respective regional geographies (RER). It represents an aggregation of the production of Elemental Chlorine Free (ECF) and Totally Chlorine Free (TCF) kraft pulp, obtained from softwood for the year 2020. Industry data was used which was provided by the European Pulp Industry Sector Association AISBL (EPIS). Values represent weighted average of 16 corresponding pulp mills located in Nordic countries and Germany. The used values are a weighted average of all corresponding pulp mills. The represented technology is considered state of the art for an European average.;PULP is a wood-based raw material to make different paper, board and other products. The pulp, or fibers from the wood are separated in a kraft cooking process in a so-called fiber line. In a recovery line, the chemicals used in the cooking process are recovered to be used again and energy is produced. The third process is effluent treatment where gaseous and liquid discharges to the environment are continuously minimized and monitored.;MAIN END USES FOR MARKET PULP • Tissue (toilet paper) • Graphic papers • Specialty products • Packaging • Fluff pulp • Viscose • CMC etc. ;PRODUCTS GENERATED IN THE PULPING PROCESS include crude tall oil, turpentine, biogas from sludge, electricity, heat etc.;CAPACITIES World’s total market capacities for softwood kraft pulp, hardwood kraft pulp, and eucalyptus kraft pulp were 28.9 million tons, 15 million tons, and 26.2 million tons, respectively.;SPECIES Softwood pulp is made from coniferous trees, most typically from different species of pine and spruce. Hardwood pulp is made from non-coniferous trees, in Nordic countries primarily of birch. Eucalyptus hardwood pulp is made exclusively of eucalyptus species.;CHARACTERISTICS Softwood fibers are long and slender and are used to give the paper and board products their strength properties. Hardwood fibers are short and can be rounder and their number per gram of pulp is much larger; they give the end product its smoothness, softness and optical properties like opacity (that you cannot see through the paper).

This activity starts with the reception of the pulpwood at the factory gate.

The process includes wood handling, chemical pulping and bleaching, drying process, energy production on-site, recovery cycles of chemicals and internal wastewater treatment. The following air emissions were reported in the industry: CO2 (fossil and biogenic), SOx (as SO2), NOx, TRS (as S), SO2 (reported as S), Dust (unspecified). Next to these key emissions, additional emissions from on-site energy production from external and internal fuels were calculated, using emission profiles from ecoinvent combustion processes. Internal biogenic fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (55MJ/t), Bark (1952MJ/t), Black liquor(18349MJ/t), Sludge (61 MJ/t), Methanol (145 MJ/t), Biomass (6 MJ/t), tall oil pitch (229 MJ/t), Biomass (wood residuals) (84 MJ/t). Black liquor, sludge, tall oil pitch, and sodium formiate were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles, e.g. for the black liquor recovery process, were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap. The production of 8.43E-06 kg of the by-product “white liquor” per kg of pulp was excluded from the activity since no appropriate proxy could be found. The activity ends when the kraft pulp is ready to be sold.
category: C:Manufacturing/17:Manufacture of paper and paper products/170:Manufacture of paper and paper products/1701:Manufacture of pulp, paper and paperboard

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data gathered in 2021 and represents data of 2020 values. Recent technology valid for the upcoming years.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from respective regional geographies (RER). Data is coming from mills in Nordic countries and Germany.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average European technology in 2020 of kraft pulp production of ECF and TCF pulp
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from respective regional geographies (RER). For the RER dataset, Industry data provided key emission factors for CO2 (biogenic), SOx (as SO2), NOx, TRS (as S), SO2 (reported as S), and Dust (unspecified). Additional air emissions resulting from on-site energy production, i.e. the combustion of fuels, were calculated based on industrial heating datasets from the ecoinvent database. The following ecoinvent combustion processes were used to estimate additional air emissions: Hard coal: heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, Europe without Switzerland; Heavy fuel oil: heat production, heavy fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland; Light fuel oil: heat production, light fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland; Biofuel - Biogas: heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW, Europe without Switzerland; Methanol: heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW, Europe without Switzerland; Natural gas: heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW, Europe without Switzerland; Biofuel - Bark (wet weight): heat production, wood chips from industry, at furnace 1000kW, CH; Biofuel - Biomass: heat production, wood chips from industry, at furnace 1000kW, CH; Biofuel - Biomass - wood residuals: heat production, wood chips from industry, at furnace 1000kW, CH; Biofuel - Bark: heat production, wood chips from industry, at furnace 1000kW, CH; Wood pellets: heat production, wood chips from industry, at furnace 1000kW, CH;. CO2, CO and CH4 emissions from biogas and methanol were modelled as non-fossil.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from respective regional geographies (RER). The RER data represents a weighted average of about 16 mills providing 86% of the European capacity of bleached kraft pulp from softwood.

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion (see "Extrapolations" comment). Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as bark, black liquor, sludge, and tall oil pitch are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (55MJ/t), Bark (1952MJ/t), Black liquor (18349MJ/t), Sludge (61 MJ/t), Methanol (145 MJ/t), Biomass (6 MJ/t), tall oil pitch (229 MJ/t), Biomass (wood residuals) (84 MJ/t).Black liquor, sludge, tall oil pitch, and sodium formiate were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (55MJ/t), Bark (1952MJ/t), Black liquor (18349MJ/t), Sludge (61 MJ/t), Methanol (145 MJ/t), Biomass (6 MJ/t), tall oil pitch (229 MJ/t), Biomass (wood residuals) (84 MJ/t).Black liquor, sludge, tall oil pitch, and sodium formiate were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion (see "Extrapolations" comment). Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as bark, black liquor, sludge, and tall oil pitch are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (55MJ/t), Bark (1952MJ/t), Black liquor (18349MJ/t), Sludge (61 MJ/t), Methanol (145 MJ/t), Biomass (6 MJ/t), tall oil pitch (229 MJ/t), Biomass (wood residuals) (84 MJ/t).Black liquor, sludge, tall oil pitch, and sodium formiate were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

exchanges.description: Data provided by industry (EPIS) 2020, indicated in energy content and given as 0.0059 MJ/kg . Calculation into mass/volume was done by using the following conversion factor 7.133 MJ/kg. LHV is calculated based on the elemental composition of the substance. Based on the CAS number of the substance (000141-53-7), the chemical formula of the substance is found to be: CHNaO2, (PubChem 2020). Reference: Kim, S., Chen, J., Cheng, T., Gindulyte, A., He, J., He, S., Li, Q., Shoemaker, B. A., Thiessen, P. A., Yu, B., Zaslavsky, L., Zhang, J., & Bolton, E. E. (2019). exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion (see "Extrapolations" comment). Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as bark, black liquor, sludge, and tall oil pitch are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (55MJ/t), Bark (1952MJ/t), Black liquor (18349MJ/t), Sludge (61 MJ/t), Methanol (145 MJ/t), Biomass (6 MJ/t), tall oil pitch (229 MJ/t), Biomass (wood residuals) (84 MJ/t).Black liquor, sludge, tall oil pitch, and sodium formiate were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (55MJ/t), Bark (1952MJ/t), Black liquor (18349MJ/t), Sludge (61 MJ/t), Methanol (145 MJ/t), Biomass (6 MJ/t), tall oil pitch (229 MJ/t), Biomass (wood residuals) (84 MJ/t).Black liquor, sludge, tall oil pitch, and sodium formiate were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion (see "Extrapolations" comment). Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as bark, black liquor, sludge, and tall oil pitch are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (55MJ/t), Bark (1952MJ/t), Black liquor (18349MJ/t), Sludge (61 MJ/t), Methanol (145 MJ/t), Biomass (6 MJ/t), tall oil pitch (229 MJ/t), Biomass (wood residuals) (84 MJ/t).Black liquor, sludge, tall oil pitch, and sodium formiate were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

exchanges.description: Data provided by industry (EPIS) 2020 Represents biofuel from tall oil pitch. Indicated in energy content and given as 0.1198 MJ/kg. Calculated from energetic value with conversion factor 26.48 MJ/kg. The LHV is calculated based on the elemental composition of the substance. Based on the CAS number of the substance (000067-56-1), the chemical formula of the substance is found to be: CH4O, (PubChem 2020). Reference: Kim, S., Chen, J., Cheng, T., Gindulyte, A., He, J., He, S., Li, Q., Shoemaker, B. A., Thiessen, P. A., Yu, B., Zaslavsky, L., Zhang, J., & Bolton, E. E. (2019). PubChem 2019 update: improved access to chemical data. Nucleic acids research, 47(D1), D1102–D1109. https://doi.org/10.1093/nar/gky1033

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion (see "Extrapolations" comment). Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as bark, black liquor, sludge, and tall oil pitch are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (55MJ/t), Bark (1952MJ/t), Black liquor (18349MJ/t), Sludge (61 MJ/t), Methanol (145 MJ/t), Biomass (6 MJ/t), tall oil pitch (229 MJ/t), Biomass (wood residuals) (84 MJ/t).Black liquor, sludge, tall oil pitch, and sodium formiate were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.
